bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 23, 1946

div1.p: Kean discusses "Special Order 83," issued by the Department of Western Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 23, 1946
div1.opener:
In re Special Order 83. Dept. of Western Cuba-
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
23 Nov. 1946
My dear Col. Hench
div1.p:
I am not as prompt in my attention
to business as you and Gen. Ireland
are, and Mrs Kean was disturbed at
the Lambert papers being still on my
desk- So last night after reading the
photostats of Dr. Brumby's speech to the
Texas Med. Assn & the other photostats, I
found an envelope that would contain
them and sealed, addressed, stamped them,
so they are ready to be mailed this morning
as soon as I can get someone to take them-
I got to thinking this morning why it was
necessary for me to have an order issued by
the Dept. of Western Cuba for Dr. Ames and
several enlisted men to be ordered to report
to Major Reed, and it all came back to me-
Of course it did not make Ames or the enlisted
men members of the Reed Board- That would
require an order from the War Dept. which
created the Board, and no one who had any
knowledge of Army administration would
ever think of such a thing- But Camp Lazier
was outside of the military reservation and
to send military personnel there for any
purpose would require an order from military
authority- The normal military authority
to issue it was the Post Commander- But
he was not a normal person, and would
probably refuse, especially if he could annoy
Gen. Wood by so doing- So I asked the
next highest military commander who was
my chief Gen Fitzhugh Lee to issue the
order, and forgot all about it, until it
3
appeared in Lambert's statement and was
given the absurd interpretation which Dr.
Brumby gave it- Ordinarily not a formal order
but only verbal approval would be necessary for
such activities so near the post- Whether orders
were issued in the cases of other men who
were on duty at Camp Lazear either as
attendants or experimental patients I do
not remember- I did not keep a copy of
Special Order 83 or any like order, They were
just ordinary details of none except tempo-
rary importance- I cannot but admire tho
persistent industry by which this S. O. was
looked up and found, and the ingenuity
by which a meaning which it never had, has been
injected into it-

I hope that you had a pleasant journey
home and do not feel that the time and
money which you expended in your trip to
washington were wasted- Your presence
at the meeting gave great pleasure to a
group of worthy “has feens” and, as my friend
Ireland thought, unduly stimulated the
loquacity of one or more of them- I have
felt that Mrs Kean's comment on our failure
to make any proper arrangements for your
entertainment was quite justified- She
said that we were all asleep at the
switch- We will do better next time.
